description: Template for all croc-type pseudosuchia. mon_gator plus Carnufex plus a saltwater croc of the same size have been used as reference. Do note that modern crocs in general scale weight by the square cubed law, so +1 m long equals x2 weight. Stats for a 3 m long animal

Template for all runner-like pseudosuchia. mon_gator plus Carnufex plus a saltwater croc of the same size have been used as reference. Do note that modern crocs in general scale weight by the square cubed law, so +1 m long equals x2 weight. Stats for a 3 m long animal
A crocoduck!
//: Based on Anatosuchus sp.. No reproductive data.

description: A small Anatosuchus.  Doesn't quack either.

An very large, crocodile-looking beast.  With the frame of an oversized gator, except for the long legs that support its body well above the ground, it wanders around with a primal hunger for smaller, slower creatures.
//: Based on Barinasuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A baby Barinasuchus.  You can pet these.  Once, mayyybe twice.

A bizarre, crocodile-like animal.  The long snout is curved in such a way that makes it look "big nosed".  The stubby legs, look almost unable to allow movement, yet the beast moves quicker than one would expect.  The back of the animal is protected by osteoderm, starting from where the shoulders would be to the end of the fat and thick tail.  Doesn't look friendly.
//: This monster is that one obsolete reconstruction but turned into an actual animal
//3: anger and fear flags are inverted
//2: Based on Belodon sp. and Nicrosaurus kapffi. No reproductive data

description: A baby Belodon.  Literally the same animal but downsized.  How original.

A large crocodile-looking animal.  It proudly stands over the ground, supported by strong legs that end in hooves.  Unlike modern crocodiles, this is perfectly capable of running not so short distances.
//: Based on Boverisuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A baby Boverisuchus.  You can swear you hear them mooing softly.
A very large tortoise.  Moving slowly in search of nourishment, it pays no attention to the world around it.  Although that doesn't mean it wouldn't retaliate if necessary.
//: Based on Carbonemys sp, assuming 1 ton. No reproductive data
//2: Add 'defensive mode' at some point lol, also reduce the hp after that

description: A baby Carbonemys.  You have to stop yourself from sitting on it.
This curious animal looks like a crocodile, but it's leaner, bipedal and it can run.  It also has two functional, if short, arms to hold prey while it takes chunks from it.
//: Based on Carnufex sp. No reproductive data

description: What's cuter than tiny crocodiles? Tiny crocodiles that can run and take chunks of your ankles.
A bizarre-looking crocodilian.  The head, which takes a third of the whole body, looks very sturdy, and very eager to crunch stuff for consumption.
//: Based on Erythrosuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A baby Erythrosuchus.  They will love libraries.

A very large, crocodile-looking beast.  Despite appearing very similar to a now outdated conception of theropods, its frame is crocodilesque once you focus on the details, with very notable differences.  For example, it can walk upright.  It is also adapted to hunt, instead of stalking for prey.  And last, but not least important, it can run.
//: Based on Fasolasuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A baby Fasolasuchus.  They're not medicinal.
A small, lean, long-legged crocodile-like animal.  It walks like a quadruped, relying only on the muscular hind limbs to sprint to catch it's prey.
//: Based on Hesperosuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A small Hesperosuchus.  Actually looks like a long-legged baby crocodile.

An animal you could mistake for a dolphin if it wasn't for some key differences.  The first one are the eyes, huge, piercing eyes coverered by sclerotic rings you feel are tracking several things at once, you included.  The second are the serrated jaws, reminding you of crocodiles and the stereotypical dinosaur.  The third are the fins, with the caudal fin being vertical, and the dorsal fin being somewhat small.
//: Ichthyosaurus communis used as reference. Don't know if they had vocalizations but that's how I imagine them to be
//2: Coprolites include fish and squid, and the big characteristic eyes indicate it could hunt in low light conditions, with great depths included

description: A smaller Ichthyosaurus.  This would be a curious animal to keep in a big fish tank in the hall, if you were the plotting villain of a movie.

A bizarre-looking animal.  Around the size of a pig, this reptile not just features a beak, but also a somewhat short sail on its back.  As if that were not enough, the front claws are prensile and able to grasp.
//: Based on Lotosaurus sp. No reproductive data

description: A Lotosaurus calf.  Sail in development.

A crocodile-looking animal, around twice longer than an alligator.  The long snout has a bump in front of the eyes, revealing the position of the nostrils, and the curious shape of the bite features a bunch of oversized front teeth to hold the doomed prey.  The base of the tail looks somewhat fat, adapted to serve as a giant paddle to impulse the animal through water, hopefully not towards yourself.
//: Based on Phytosaurus cylindricodon, except this one's herbivore. No reproductive data

description: A baby Phytosaurus.  This *does* seem to be eating plants‚Ä¶

An animal that looks like certain Scottish cryptid.  It has a characteristic long neck with a small head.  The animal paddles through water as it moves its head side to side to catch fish.  The overall aspect and size are somewhat disappointing.
//: Plesiosaurus dolichodeirus used as reference, Plesiosaurus is a wastebasket taxon

description: A small Nessie.
An imponent, crocodile-looking beast.  Large enough to be confused with a saur, it walks upright, unlike its modern counterparts.  Worse for you, it looks very capable of running.
//: Based on Prestosuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A baby Prestosuchus.  Young enough to not shave.

A crocodile-looking animal, much longer than an alligator.  The very long snout has a bump in front of the eyes, revealing the position of the nostrils, and the curious shape of the bite features a bunch of oversized front teeth to hold the doomed prey.  The base of the tail looks somewhat fat, adapted to serve as a giant paddle to impulse the animal through water, hopefully not towards yourself.
//: Based on Redondasaurus sp (alternatively, this is Machaeroprosopus). No reproductive data

description: A "small" Redondasaurus, the size of a big dog.  Isn't that round.

A big, muscular looking reptile.  The head features a bunch of horns, growing from the cheeks and pointing forwards.  The body is also covered, by smaller protective scales.  The upright posture is supported by the stout limbs, in contrast with the short tail, almost stub-like.
//: Based on Scutosaurus sp. No reproductive data. Probably lived alone?

description: A Scutosaurus calf.  Could probably lift you.
A small crocodile-like animal.  Its size, around that of a dog or a large cat, alongside its short snout makes it look quite unthreatening.
//: Based on Simosuchus sp. No reproductive data

description: A small Simosuchus.  It's like a croco-rat.

A crocodile-looking animal, around twice longer than an alligator.  The long snout has a bump in front of the eyes, revealing the position of the nostrils, and the curious shape of the bite features a bunch of oversized front teeth to hold the doomed prey.  The base of the tail looks somewhat fat, adapted to serve as a giant paddle to impulse the animal through water, hopefully not towards yourself.
//: Based on Smilosuchus gregorii. No reproductive data

description: A "small" Smilosuchus, the size of a big dog.  Like the adult version, this doesn't actually make you smile.

A bizarre-looking animal.  The whole wide body is protected by osteoderm that goes from the neck to the end of the tail, which is even more armored.  The back limbs are twice as large as the front limbs, giving it a permanently sloped walk.  The disproportionally small, conical head is somewhat flattened towards the snout.  The neck features one large bony horn at each side, which is unlikely to serve as protection.
//: Based on Typothorax sp. No reproductive data

description: A Typothorax calf.  Will widen in a few months.

A flying lizard-looking creature, with two twists.  First, the wings extend from the sides of the animal, instead of the arms, which leaves them free, and give it a curious appearance mid flight.  Second, it actually doesn't fly, but glides.
//: Based on Weigeltisaurus sp.. No reproductive data

description: A small Weigeltisaurus.  The way it flaps around is cute.
